headline.main: Study Finds Secondhand Smoke Doubles Risk of Heart Disease

docs.abstract: 10-year study by Harvard University researchers finds secondhand cigarette smoke is more dangerous than previously thought, and can double risk of heart disease; shows biggest increase in risk ever reported, which researchers say applies equally to men and women; tracked more that 32,000 healthy women, ranging in age from 36 to 61, who were nonsmokers; findings discussed; chart (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Secondhand cigarette smoke is more dangerous than previously thought, Harvard researchers are reporting today in a study with broad implications for public health policy and probable direct impact on at least one major lawsuit. The 10-year study, which tracked more than 32,000 healthy women who never smoked, has found that regular exposure to other peoples' smoking at home or work almost doubled the risk of heart disease.

headline.main: It's Still Too Early to Judge School Vouchers

docs.abstract: Bruce Fuller letter on school voucher programs; holds there is insufficient evidence yet to judge success of school voucher experiments
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Twice recently you have usefully shined a bright light on the Milwaukee school voucher experiment (Editorial Notebook, May 15; editorial, April 25). This program is challenging an encrusted school bureaucracy and has spawned voucher-like initiatives around the country, including New York City's new private scholarship program. But it is troubling to see you endorse studies -- claiming learning gains by Milwaukee's voucher students -- that are flawed.

headline.main: Another Weapon in the Diet Wars

docs.abstract: Editorial says while new diet pill Xenical could become another useful backup weapon in diet wars, primary way to lose weight is to eat sensibly and exercise regularly (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: When it comes to diets, Americans are constantly searching for a quick fix. After all, it is a lot easier for many couch potatoes to pop a pill than to push away that greasy hamburger and french fries or spend 20 minutes on the treadmill. The latest magic bullet is a diet pill called Xenical that can reduce absorption of fat by as much as a third. An advisory committee of the Food and Drug Administration has recommended that the agency approve the pill. It could become another useful backup weapon in the diet wars, but the primary way to lose weight remains, as always, to eat sensibly and exercise regularly.
